docBody.p: Here is one spot on Earth where statesmanship is in action. The Health Department invited me to come here and give a series of talks to the groups who constitute the leaders in various clinic and educational activities.

It is encouraging to find here officials in Government positions with courage to act and vision to see that certain actions now can prevent adverse, deplorable conditions later on. This is one of the garden spots in the world with a lovely climate and quaint charming traditions of locomotion--the horse & buggy and the bicycle. White washed houses built of coral stone are 250 years old. The population is about 30,000, having increased 10,000 in less than ten years. There are 19 square miles and “a density of population, said Col. Dill, beaten only by Malta, Hong Kong and Gibraltar.”

The first meeting took place in a committee room of the House of Assembly. Members of the House of Assembly and of the Legislative Council with members of the Board of Health and His Lordship, the Bishop of Bermuda, listened attentively to the address. Col. Dill was in the Chair.

The death rates here are declining owing to able medical care. The colored population has a higher birth rate than the whites. But 60% of the population is colored. Birth rate in 1936 for white population was 16.4, for colored 29.2. While the death rates for the same year were: whites 8.8--colored 9.6. Infant mortality: whites 45.8--colored 52.9. The increase is far too rapid for future peace and comfort. Since U.S.A. refuses to allow alien immigration thus bars out a large proportion of the population who went to U.S.A. for service (comestic) each year.

The conditions here at present are good. There is no unemployment--no relief. It is a tourist place and as long as people of wealth travel, Bermuda can be prosperous and happy. But is to the future that one must look and the present Governor, Lt. Gen. R. J. T. Hildyard, an army man of strong personality, is keen and anxious to see that the population of Bermuda shall keep its standards high and retain the conditions of harmony, respect, peace and good will toward each other it now attains.

This can be done it is agreed providing the population increases slowly and not rapidly, allowing for higher educational facilities and the assimilation of the population into the system now prevailing. There are no income or inheritance taxes in Bermuda. The average wage for unskilled workers is $15 to $18 a week (L 3.10)

If any one desires to see what can come to people in an overcrowded land, just take a trip to Puerto Rico and see for oneself the appalling conditions that breeding and increasing regardless of conditions can bring humanity to. At last Puerto Rico has come to its senses and the legislation passed? a law allowing birth control to be taught to its people.
Bermuda is fortunate in having statesmanship at its head. My congratulations and best wishes. Let us watch and see what the future will bring.
